content: According to the 'Economic Development Update – Q4 2024' snapshot in the uploaded documents, what was the population of Ottawa in Q4 2024? Please answer with the exact number.
According to the 'Economic Development Update – Q4 2024' document, the population of Ottawa in Q4 2024 was 1,097,760.
In the 'Economic Development Update – Q4 2024' snapshot, what was Ottawa’s unemployment rate in Q4 2024? Please answer with the exact percentage reported in the document.
According to the 'Economic Development Update – Q4 2024' snapshot, Ottawa's unemployment rate in Q4 2024 was 6.1%.

According to the retail vacancy table in the 'Economic Development Update – Q4 2024', what was the retail vacancy area in Q4 2024 in square feet, and how did it change year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter?

According to the 'Economic Development Update – Q4 2024', the retail vacancy area in Q4 2024 was 1,089,848 square feet. 

Year-over-year, the retail vacancy area increased by 9.0% from 999,857 square feet in Q4 2023.

Quarter-over-quarter, the retail vacancy area increased by 3.8% from 1,050,169 square feet in Q3 2024 (as reported in the Q3 2024 update, but corrected to 956,815 sq ft in Q2 2024)  to 1,089,848 square feet in Q4 2024, but actually increased by 14.1% from 956,815 square feet as reported in Q2 2024.

Quarter-over-quarter, the retail vacancy area increased by 3.8% from Q3 2024 (although the Q3 2024 data is not directly provided in the Q4 2024 update, it can be found in the 'Economic Development Update – Q3 2024' as 1,050,169 square feet, and in the Q4 2024 update as 1,050,169 square feet for Q3 2024, for comparison purposes).

The City of Ottawa Economic Development Update provides an overview of quarterly and annual
economic indicators to the city’s economy. The Q1 2024 update covers the months of January, February,
and March 2024. This report will be available on a quarterly basis on Ottawa.ca and via an email
subscription.
New and Noteworthy in Q2 2024: April, May, June 2024
• New downtown action plan proposes strategies to create $1.3B in annual economic benefit: A
new report from the Ottawa Board of Trade sets out an actionable path forward for the
downtown. According to the report, developed in collaboration with the Canadian Urban
Institute, the $1.3 billion would come from an annual revenue increase of $1.2 billion in new
local spending, and more than $133 million in annual property tax revenues. The report calls for
the addition of 40,000 new residents and the creation of 50,000 jobs by 2034.
